# 2. Higher COMPlex SObOLEV SPace 

In this section, we prove some basic properties and give examples of our spaces. We also study their corresponding functional capacities.
2.1. Quasinorms and compactness. We now define some norms and quasinorms on $W_{q}^{*}$. First, we consider the local setting. Let $\Omega$ be a bounded domain in $\mathbb{C}^{k}$ and $\varphi \in$ $W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$. Then by definition, there exist psh functions $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}$ in $\Omega$ such that

$$
\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right\|<\infty \text { and } d \varphi_{j-1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j-1} \leq d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \text { for all } j=1, \ldots, q
$$

Here we put $\varphi_{0}:=\varphi$. We call a sequence $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ satisfying (2.1) is a defining sequence of $\varphi$ in $W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$. We define the $q$-star quasinorm for $W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$ as follows

$$
\|\varphi\|_{W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)}:=\|\varphi\|_{L^{2}(\Omega)}+\inf \left\{\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}\right\}
$$

where the infimum is taken over all defining sequence $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ of $\varphi$. It is easy to see that one can replace inf by min in the definition (2.2).

Next, we consider the global setting. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of dimension $k$ and $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$. Then by definition, there exist qpsh functions $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}$ in $X$ and constants $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{q} \geq 0$ such that

$$
d \varphi_{j-1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j-1} \leq c_{j} \omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \text { for all } j=1, \ldots, q
$$

Here we put $\varphi_{0}:=\varphi$. We call a sequence $\left(\left(c_{1}, \varphi_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(c_{q}, \varphi_{q}\right)\right)$ satisfying (2.3) is a defining sequence of $\varphi$ in $W_{q}^{*}(X)$. We define the $q$-star norm for $W^{*}(X)$ as follows

$$
\|\varphi\|_{W_{q}^{*}(X)}:=\|\varphi\|_{L^{2}(X)}+\inf \left\{\sum_{j=1}^{q} c_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}\right\}
$$

where the infimum is taken over all defining sequence $\left(\left(c_{1}, \varphi_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(c_{q}, \varphi_{q}\right)\right)$ of $\varphi$. As in the local case, one can replace inf by min in the definition (2.4). We note also that by Poincaré-Wirtinger inequality, if we replace $L^{2}$ in the definition of $\|\cdot\|_{W_{q}^{*}(X)}$ by $L^{1}$, we obtain an equivalent quasinorm. In the sequel, for simplicity, we will use the notation

$\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$ instead of $\|\cdot\|_{W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)}$ and $\|\cdot\|_{W_{q}^{*}(X)}$ when there is no possible confusion of the domain.

Proposition 2.1. The function $\varphi \mapsto\|\varphi\|_{*, q}$ defines a quasinorm on $W_{q}^{*}$.
Proof. We begin with the local setting. We first check the homogeneity. Let $\psi=\lambda \varphi$, then $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ is a defining sequence for $\varphi$ iff $\left(|\lambda|^{2} \varphi_{1}, \ldots,|\lambda|^{2^{q}} \varphi_{q}\right)$ is a defining sequence for $\psi$. Hence, $\|\psi\|_{*, q}=|\lambda|\|\varphi\|_{*, q}$.

We now only need to check the quasi-triangle inequality. Let $\varphi$ and $\psi$ be functions in $W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$ where $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ and $\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{q}\right)$ are two corresponding defining sequences. Put $f=\varphi+\psi$. We claim that $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{q}\right)$, with $f_{j}=\frac{4^{2^{j-1}}}{2}\left(\varphi_{j}+\psi_{j}\right)$, is a defining sequence of $f$ satisfying

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{\circ} f_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}} \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{\circ} \varphi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{\circ} \psi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}\right)
$$

We prove it by induction on $q$. For $q=1$, we have

$$
d f \wedge d^{\circ} f=d \varphi \wedge d^{\circ} \varphi+d \psi \wedge d^{\circ} \psi+\left(d \varphi \wedge d^{\circ} \psi+d \psi \wedge d^{\circ} \varphi\right)
$$

It follows from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality that

$$
d \varphi \wedge d^{\circ} \psi+d \psi \wedge d^{\circ} \varphi \leq d \varphi \wedge d^{\circ} \varphi+d \psi \wedge d^{\circ} \psi
$$

This implies that $d f \wedge d^{\circ} f \leq 2\left(d \varphi \wedge d^{\circ} \varphi+d \psi \wedge d^{\circ} \psi\right) \leq d d^{\circ}\left(2 \varphi_{1}+2 \psi_{1}\right)$. Then for $f_{1}=$ $2\left(\varphi_{1}+\psi_{1}\right)$, we have

$$
d f \wedge d^{\circ} f \leq d d^{\circ} f_{1} \text { and }\left\|d d^{\circ} f_{1}\right\|^{1 / 2} \leq \sqrt{2}\left(\left\|d d^{\circ} \varphi_{1}\right\|^{1 / 2}+\left\|d d^{\circ} \psi_{1}\right\|^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

Hence, the proof for $q=1$ is complete.
Now, we assume that the desired property is true for $q-1$ where $q \geq 2$. We have $f_{q-1}=$ $\frac{4^{2^{q-2}}}{2}\left(\varphi_{q-1}+\psi_{q-1}\right)$. It thus follows from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the definition of defining sequences that

$$
d f_{q-1} \wedge d^{\circ} f_{q-1} \leq \frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2} d d^{\circ}\left(\varphi_{q}+\psi_{q}\right)
$$

Then for $f_{q}=\frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2}\left(\varphi_{q}+\psi_{q}\right)$, we have

$$
d f_{q-1} \wedge d^{\circ} f_{q-1} \leq d d^{\circ} f_{q} \text { and }\left\|d d^{\circ} f_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}} \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\left\|d d^{\circ} \varphi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}+\left\|d d^{\circ} \psi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}\right)
$$

Thus, by the induction hypothesis, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{\circ} f_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}} & =\sum_{j=1}^{q-1}\left\|d d^{\circ} f_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}+\left\|d d^{\circ} f_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}} \\
& \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q-1}}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{q-1}\left\|d d^{\circ} \varphi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q-1}\left\|d d^{\circ} \psi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}\right) \\
& +2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\left\|d d^{\circ} \varphi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}+\left\|d d^{\circ} \psi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}\right) \\
& \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{\circ} \varphi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{\circ} \psi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as desired.

Next, we consider the global setting. The homogeneity is clear. Now let $\varphi$ and $\psi$ be functions in $W_{q}^{*}(X)$ where $\left(\left(\alpha_{1}, \varphi_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\alpha_{q}, \varphi_{q}\right)\right)$ and $\left(\left(\beta_{1}, \psi_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\beta_{q}, \psi_{q}\right)\right)$ are corresponding defining sequences. Let $f=\varphi+\psi$. As in the local case, it is sufficient to prove that $\left(\left(\gamma_{1}, f_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\gamma_{q}, f_{q}\right)\right)$, with $\gamma_{j}=\frac{4^{q^{j-1}}}{2}\left(\alpha_{j}+\beta_{j}\right)$ and $f_{j}=\frac{4^{q^{j-1}}}{2}\left(\varphi_{j}+\psi_{j}\right)$, is a defining sequence of $f$ satisfying

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{q} \gamma_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}} \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{q} \alpha_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q} \beta_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}\right)
$$

We prove it by induction on $q$. For $q=1$, the same computation as in the local case gives

$$
d f \wedge d^{c} f \leq\left(2 \alpha_{1}+2 \beta_{1}\right) \omega+d d^{c}\left(2 \varphi_{1}+2 \psi_{1}\right)
$$

Then for $\gamma_{1}=2\left(\alpha_{1}+\beta_{1}\right)$ and $f_{1}=2\left(\varphi_{1}+\psi_{1}\right)$, we have

$$
d f \wedge d^{c} f \leq \gamma_{1} \omega+d d^{c} f_{1} \text { and } \gamma_{1}^{1 / 2} \leq \sqrt{2}\left(\alpha_{1}^{1 / 2}+\beta_{1}^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

This finishes the proof for $q=1$. Now we assume that the desired property is true for $q-1$ where $q \geq 2$. We have $\gamma_{q-1}=\frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2}\left(\alpha_{q-1}+\beta_{q-1}\right)$ and $f_{q-1}=\frac{4^{2^{q-2}}}{2}\left(\varphi_{q-1}+\psi_{q-1}\right)$. It thus follows from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the definition of defining sequences that

$$
d f_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} f_{q-1} \leq \frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2}\left(\alpha_{q}+\beta_{q}\right) \omega+\frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2} d d^{c}\left(\varphi_{q}+\psi_{q}\right)
$$

Then for $\gamma_{q}=\frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2}\left(\alpha_{q}+\beta_{q}\right)$ and $f_{q}=\frac{4^{2^{q-1}}}{2}\left(\varphi_{q}+\psi_{q}\right)$, we have

$$
d f_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} f_{q-1} \leq \gamma_{q} \omega+d d^{c} f_{q} \text { and } \gamma_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}} \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\alpha_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}+\beta_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}\right)
$$

It thus follows from the induction hypothesis that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{j=1}^{q} \gamma_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}} & =\sum_{j=1}^{q-1} \gamma_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}+\gamma_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}} \\
& \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q-1}}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{q-1} \alpha_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q-1} \beta_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}\right)+2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\alpha_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}+\beta_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}\right) \\
& \leq 2^{1-1 / 2^{q}}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{q} \alpha_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q} \beta_{j}^{1 / 2^{j}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as desired. The proof is complete.
We now consider a different norm on $W_{q}^{*}$. In the local setting, we define

$$
\|\varphi\|_{* *, q}:=\|\varphi\|_{L^{2}(\Omega)}+\inf \left\{\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}\right\}
$$

where the infimum is taken over all defining sequence $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ of $\varphi$. In the global setting, we define

$$
\|\varphi\|_{* *, q}=\|\varphi\|_{L^{2}(X)}+\inf \left\{c_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}\right\}
$$

where the infimum is taken over all defining sequence $\left(\left(c_{1}, \varphi_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(c_{q}, \varphi_{q}\right)\right)$ of $\varphi$.
Proposition 2.2. The function $\varphi \mapsto\|\varphi\|_{* *, q}$ defines a norm on $W_{q}^{*}$.

Proof. We use the idea of [Vig07, Proposition 1]. We prove the local case only as the global case can be treated similarly (see the proof of Proposition 2.1).

The homogeneity is clear. We only need to check the triangle inequality. Let $\varphi$ and $\psi$ be functions in $W_{q}^{*}$ and $f:=\varphi+\psi$. Let $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ and $\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{q}\right)$ be defining sequences for $\varphi$ and $\psi$. Let $c$ be a positive number. We claim that $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{q}\right)$ with

$$
f_{j}:=(1+c)^{2^{j}-1} \varphi_{j}+(1+1 / c)^{2^{j}-1} \psi_{j}
$$

is a defining sequence for $f$.
We prove this by induction on $q$. By Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d f \wedge d^{c} f & \leq(1+c) d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi+(1+1 / c) d \psi \wedge d^{c} \psi \\
& \leq d d^{c}\left((1+c) \varphi_{1}+(1+1 / c) \psi_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim follows for $q=1$. Assume that the claim is true for $q=1$ where $q \geq 2$. We have $f_{q-1}:=(1+c)^{2^{q-1}-1} \varphi_{q-1}+(1+1 / c)^{2^{q-1}-1} \psi_{q-1}$. Using Cauchy-Schwarz inequality again, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d f_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} f_{q-1} & \leq(1+c)(1+c)^{2^{q}-2} d \varphi_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{q-1} \\
& +(1+1 / c)(1+1 / c)^{2^{q}-2} d \psi_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} \psi_{q-1} \\
& \leq d d^{c}\left((1+c)^{2^{q}-1} \varphi_{q}+(1+1 / c)^{2^{q}-1} \psi_{q}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim follows.
We now put $\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{q}\right\|=\alpha_{q},\left\|d d^{c} \psi_{q}\right\|=\beta_{q}$ and choose $c:=\left(\beta_{q} / \alpha_{q}\right)^{1 / 2^{q}}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|d d^{c} f_{q}\right\| & =\left((1+c)^{2^{q}-1} \alpha_{q}+(1+1 / c)^{2^{q}-1} \beta_{q}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\alpha_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}+\beta_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}\right)^{2^{q}-1} \alpha_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}+\left(\alpha_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}+\beta_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}\right)^{2^{q}-1} \beta_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}} \\
& =\left(\alpha_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}+\beta_{q}^{1 / 2^{q}}\right)^{2^{q}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the power $2^{-q}$, we get $\left\|d d^{c} f_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}} \leq\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}+\left\|d d^{c} \psi_{q}\right\|^{1 / 2^{q}}$ as desired.
Proposition 2.3. Let $K$ be a relatively compact subset of $\Omega$. Then there exists a constant $C$ depending only on $K$ and $\Omega$ such that $C\|\varphi\|_{W_{q}^{*}(K)} \leq\|\varphi\|_{* *, q} \leq\|\varphi\|_{*, q}$.
Proof. The second inequality is clear. For the first inequality, let $\chi$ be a cut-off function with compact support in $\Omega$ such that $\chi \equiv 1$ on $K$. Let $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}$ and $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ be a defining sequence that minimize (2.5). By Stokes' formula and Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{K} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1} & \leq \int_{\Omega} \chi d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}=\left|\int_{\Omega} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right| \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\Omega} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)^{1 / 2} \cdot\left(\int_{\Omega} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq C\left(\int_{\Omega} d d^{c} \varphi_{j+1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $1 \leq j<q$. The result follows.
Remark 2.4. It is natural to consider the quasinorm $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$ since it takes information of all the elements in the defining sequence. Proposition 2.3 implies that if we only need to control the data in a compact subset, then we can construct a norm $(\|\cdot\|_{* *, q})$ equivalent to the quasinorm $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$. Moreover, Theorem 1.2 is still true if we replace $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$ by $\|\cdot\|_{* *, q}$.

However, it is not true in the global setting because one cannot bound $c_{j}$ by some constant times $c_{j+1}$ (this is a different point in the global setting). It is interesting to know if we can build a norm in $W_{q}^{*}$ equivalent to $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$. When $q \geq 2$, since the mass of elements in the defining sequence can be chosen independently with each other (one can consider the 1-dimensional case to see why), it seems to us that such a norm does not exist.
Remark 2.5. Note that when the domain $\Omega$ is nice (e.g., convex domain), we have $W_{1}^{*}=$ $W^{*}$. This restriction is from the fact that we cannot solve the equation $d d^{c} \varphi=T$ in every domain. We also note that the spaces $W_{q}^{*}$ is decreasing in $q$.

By using induction on $q$ and the idea of [Vig07, Proposition 4], it is easy to prove that $W_{q}^{*}$ has the following compactness property.
Proposition 2.6. Let $\left(\varphi_{n}\right)$ be a bounded sequence in $W_{q}^{*}$. Then there exists a subsequence $\left(\varphi_{n_{j}}\right)$ and a function $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}$ such that $\varphi_{n_{j}}$ converges weakly to $\varphi$ in $W^{1,2}$ and $\|\varphi\|_{*, q} \leq$ $\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\varphi_{n_{j}}\right\|_{*, q}$.

Now, we prove that with the quasinorm $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}, W_{q}^{*}$ is a quasi-Banach space.
Proposition 2.7. $W_{q}^{*}$ endowed with the quasinorm $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$ is a quasi-Banach space.
Proof. We prove by induction on $q$. For $q=1$, this is a slight modification of [Vig07, Proposition 1]. Suppose that $W_{q-1}^{*}$ is a quasi-Banach space endowed with the quasinorm $\|\cdot\|_{*, q-1}$ for $q \geq 2$. Let $\left(\varphi_{n}\right)$ be a Cauchy sequence in $W_{q}^{*}$, then it is also a Cauchy sequence in $W_{q-1}^{*}$. Thus it converges to a function $\varphi \in W_{q-1}^{*}$. For every $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $N$ such that for $m, n>N$, we have $d\left(\varphi_{n}-\varphi_{m}\right) \wedge d^{c}\left(\varphi_{n}-\varphi_{m}\right) \leq d d^{c} \psi_{n, m}$, where $\psi_{n, m}$ is a function with $\left\|\psi_{n, m}\right\|_{*, q-1}<\varepsilon$. By Proposition 2.6, we can find a subsequence of $\left(\psi_{n, m}\right)_{n}$ which converges weakly in $W^{1,2}$ to a function $\psi_{m}$ such that $d\left(\varphi-\varphi_{m}\right) \wedge d^{c}\left(\varphi-\varphi_{m}\right) \leq d d^{c} \psi_{m}$ and $\left\|\psi_{m}\right\|_{*, q-1} \leq \varepsilon$. Thus, $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}$ and $\varphi_{n} \rightarrow \varphi$ in $W_{q}^{*}$.
Remark 2.8. We can prove that $W_{q}^{*}$ endowed with the norm $\|\cdot\|_{*, q}$ is a Banach space by using similar arguments in the proof of Proposition 2.7.
2.2. Examples. We now give specific examples for the functions in $W_{q}^{*}$.

Example 2.9. Let $\varphi$ be a psh function in $\Omega$. Assume that $\varphi$ satisfies the following condition

$$
d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq r d d^{c} \varphi
$$

for some $r>0$. Then it is clear by induction that $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$ for all $q$. Condition (2.7) was introduced in [DF83] and has many applications in studying the Bergman kernel of $\Omega$ (see, for example, [BC00, Bło13]).
Example 2.10. Let $\varphi$ be an $\omega$-psh function in a compact Kähler manifold $(X, \omega)$. If $\varphi$ is bounded (assume that $0 \leq \varphi \leq 1$ ), then we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi=d d^{c}\left(\varphi^{2}\right) / 2-\varphi d d^{c} \varphi \leq \omega+d d^{c}\left(\varphi^{2}\right) / 2 \\
d\left(\varphi^{2} / 2\right) \wedge d^{c}\left(\varphi^{2} / 2\right)=\varphi^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq \omega+d d^{c}\left(\varphi^{2} / 2\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

We can choose $\left(\left(1, \varphi^{2} / 2\right), \ldots,\left(1, \varphi^{2} / 2\right)\right)$ to be a defining sequence for $\varphi$. Hence $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$ for all $q$ and we have the inclusion $\operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega) \cap L^{\infty} \subset \cap_{q} W_{q}^{*}(X)$.

If $\varphi$ is unbounded (assume that $\varphi \leq-1$ ). Let $\psi=-\log (-\varphi)$. We have

$$
d \psi \wedge d^{c} \psi=\frac{d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi}{|\varphi|^{2}} \text { and } d d^{c} \psi=-\frac{d d^{c} \varphi}{\varphi}+\frac{d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi}{|\varphi|^{2}}
$$

This implies that $d \psi \wedge d^{c} \psi=d d^{c} \psi+d d^{c} \varphi / \varphi \leq d d^{c} \psi+\omega$. We can choose $((1, \psi), \ldots,(1, \psi))$ to be a defining sequence for $\psi$. Therefore, $\psi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$ for all q. See also [DS06a, Lemma 4.2] and [Vig07, Example 1].

Example 2.11. It has been observed in [Vig07, Section 2.3] (see also [DS06a, Proposition 4.1]) that if $\varphi, \psi \in W_{q}^{*}$, then

$$
d \max (\varphi, \psi) \wedge d^{c} \max (\varphi, \psi)+d \min (\varphi, \psi) \wedge d^{c} \min (\varphi, \psi) \leq d d^{c}\left(\varphi_{1}+\psi_{1}\right)
$$

where $\varphi_{1}, \psi_{1}$ are functions in $W_{q-1}^{*}$ such that $d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq d d^{c} \varphi_{1}$ and $d \psi \wedge d^{c} \psi \leq d d^{c} \psi_{1}$. So, both $\max (\varphi, \psi)$ and $\min (\varphi, \psi)$ belong to $W_{q}^{*}$ and

$$
\|\max (\varphi, \psi)\|_{* q} \leq 2\left(\|\varphi\|_{*, q}+\|\psi\|_{*, q}\right) \text { and }\|\min (\varphi, \psi)\|_{*, q} \leq 2\left(\|\varphi\|_{*, q}+\|\psi\|_{*, q}\right)
$$

Example 2.12. The following example is a higher version of [Vig07, Example 2]. Let $\varphi$ be the function defined by $-\left(-\log \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\right)^{\alpha}$ in the unit ball $\mathbb{B}$ of $\mathbb{C}^{k}$. Then

$$
i \partial \varphi \wedge \bar{\partial} \varphi=\frac{i d z_{1} \wedge d \bar{z}_{1}}{\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\left(-\log \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\right)^{2-2 \alpha}}
$$

Let $\psi=-\left(-\log \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\right)^{2 \alpha}$. We have

$$
\bar{\partial} \psi=2 \alpha\left(-\log \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\right)^{2 \alpha-1} \frac{1}{\bar{z}_{1}} d \bar{z}_{1}, \quad i \partial \bar{\partial} \psi=2 \alpha(1-2 \alpha) \frac{i d z_{1} \wedge d \bar{z}_{1}}{\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\left(-\log \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\right)^{2-2 \alpha}}
$$

This implies that

$$
i \partial \varphi \wedge \bar{\partial} \varphi=\frac{1}{2 \alpha(1-2 \alpha)} i \partial \bar{\partial} \psi
$$

By induction on $q$, we have $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$ if and only if $\alpha<1 / 2^{q}$. This example will be used frequently to distinguish $W_{q}^{*}$ with different $q$ (see also Example 3.8).

Example 2.13. We consider the vanishing mean oscillation (VMO) property of functions in $W_{q}^{*}$. We highlight that this kind of property plays an important role in [DNV25].

Let $u$ be a subharmonic function in $W^{1,2}(U)$ where $U$ is an open subset of $\mathbb{C}$. Then for any ball $B \subset U$, by Poincaré-Sobolev inequality, we have

$$
\frac{1}{|B|} \int_{B}\left|u-m_{B}(u)\right| \leq c\left(\int_{B}|\nabla u|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

where $c$ is a constant not depending on $u$ and $B$. Letting the radius of $B$ goes to zero, we deduce that $\varphi$ is a VMO function. Thus, as pointed out in [BW24, Theorem 1.1], u must have zero Lelong number at every point of $U$.

Let $\varphi$ be a psh function in $W_{1}^{*}(\Omega)$. By the slicing method (see [DMV23]) and Siu's theorem (see [Dem, Chapter. III (7.13)]), $\varphi$ must have zero Lelong number at every point of $\Omega$. By the remark after [Vig07, Proposition 6], we deduce that $W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$ is a VMO space for every $q>1$. The same result holds in the global setting. In fact, as we will see in Theorem 1.3, if $\varphi \in W_{1}^{*}(X) \cap \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$, then $\varphi \in \mathcal{E}(X, \omega)$. And it is well known that functions in $\mathcal{E}(X, \omega)$ have zero Lelong numbers at every point.
2.3. Density theorems. We now prove density theorems for $W_{q}^{*}$. The approximate sequences have been constructed in [Vig07], and we use the same construction for our spaces.

First, we consider the local case. We have the following result.

Theorem 2.14. Let $K$ be a relatively compact subset of $\Omega$ and $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)$. Then there exists a sequence of smooth functions $\left(\varphi_{n}\right)$ converges to $\varphi$ in $W^{1,2}(K)$. Moreover, we have

$$
\|\varphi\|_{W_{q}^{*}(K)} \leq \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\varphi_{n}\right\|_{W_{q}^{*}(K)} \leq\|\varphi\|_{W_{q}^{*}(\Omega)}
$$

Proof. Take $\chi$ to be a non-negative smooth radial function with compact support in $\mathbb{C}^{k}$ such that $\int_{\mathbb{C}^{k}} \chi=1$ and define $\chi_{\varepsilon}(z)=\varepsilon^{-2 k} \chi(z / \varepsilon)$. Put $\varphi_{\varepsilon}=\varphi * \chi_{\varepsilon}$, then $\varphi_{\varepsilon}$ is well-defined in $K$ when $\varepsilon$ is small enough. Let $\psi \in W_{q-1}^{*}(\Omega) \cap \operatorname{PSH}(\Omega)$ such that $d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq d d^{c} \psi$. Let $\left(\varepsilon_{n}\right)_{n}$ be a sequence decreasing to zero. Define $\varphi_{n}=\varphi_{\varepsilon_{n}}, \psi_{n}=\psi * \chi_{\varepsilon_{n}}$. By [Vig07, Lemma 5], we have $d \varphi_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{n} \leq d d^{c} \psi_{n}$.

Now, let $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ be a defining sequence for $\varphi$ and put $\varphi_{n, j}=\varphi_{j} * \chi_{\varepsilon_{n}}$ for $j=$ $1, \ldots, q$. By induction, $\left(\varphi_{n, 1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n, q}\right)$ is a defining sequence for $\varphi_{n}$. Moreover, we also have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_{K} d d^{c} \varphi_{n, j} \wedge \omega^{k-1} \leq \int_{\Omega} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1} \text { for } j=1, \ldots, q
$$

It follows that $\left(\varphi_{n}\right)$ is a bounded sequence in $W_{q}^{*}(K)$. Thus, by Proposition 2.6, there exists a subsequence $\left(\varphi_{n_{m}}\right)$ converges to $\varphi$ in $W^{1,2}(K)$ and satisfies the first inequality. By (2.8), this sequence also satisfies the second inequality. The proof is complete.

We now consider the case of compact Kähler manifolds. We have the following result.
Theorem 2.15. Let $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$. Then there exists a sequence of smooth functions $\left(\varphi_{n}\right)$ such that $\varphi_{n}$ converges to $\varphi$ weakly in $W^{1,2}(X)$. Moreover, there is a constant $c$ that does not depend on $\varphi$ such that $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\varphi_{n}\right\|_{*, q} \leq c\|\varphi\|_{*, q}$.

Proof. The proof is similar to [Vig07, Theorem 10] (see also [DNV25, Theorem 2.2] for a stronger version) so we only sketch it and refer the reader to cited papers for more details. Recall that by [DS04], there exist two sequences $\left(K_{n}^{+}\right),\left(K_{n}^{-}\right)$of positive closed $(k, k)$ currents in $X \times X$ such that $K_{n}:=K_{n}^{+}-K_{n}^{-}$converges to the current of integration on the diagonal of $X \times X$. These currents are smooth outside the diagonal and $\left\|K_{n}^{ \pm}(\cdot, y)\right\|_{L^{1}} \leq A$ where $A$ is a constant that depends only on $(X, \omega)$.

Consider $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$ and put

$$
\varphi_{n}(x)=\int_{y \in X} \varphi(y) K_{n}(x, y)
$$

Let $\psi$ be the function in $W_{q-1}^{*}(X)$ such that $d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq c(\omega+d d^{c} \psi)$. Then we can bound $d \varphi_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{n}$ by the positive closed current

$$
c A \int_{y \in X}\left(K_{n}^{+}(x, y)+K_{n}^{-}(x, y)\right) \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right)
$$

We can bound this current by $2 c A^{2}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \psi_{n}\right)$, where $\psi_{n}:=\int_{y \in X} \psi(y) K_{n}^{ \pm}(x, y)$. After iterating this convolution several times, we can make $\varphi_{n}$ smooth. The result follows by induction on $q$.
2.4. Functional capacities. Consider the case where $(X, \omega)$ is a compact Kähler manifold. Following [Vig07], for a Borel set $E$ in $X$, we define

$$
L_{q}(E)=\left\{\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X): \varphi \leq-1 \text { a.e on some neighborhood of } E \text { and } \varphi \leq 0 \text { on } X\right\}
$$

The corresponding functional capacity for $W_{q}^{*}$ can be defined as follows

$$
\operatorname{Cap}_{q}(E)=\inf \left\{\|\varphi\|_{*, q}^{2}: \varphi \in L_{q}(E)\right\}
$$

These capacities share similar properties with the functional capacity introduced by Vigny in [Vig07]. We list below some important properties. The proofs are modifications of Vigny's proofs in [Vig07].

Proposition 2.16. The capacity $\mathrm{Cap}_{q}$ satisfies the following properties
(1) for $E \subset F \subset X, \operatorname{Cap}_{q}(E) \leq \operatorname{Cap}_{q}(F)$;
(2) if $\left(E_{j}\right)$ is a sequence of Borel sets in $X, \operatorname{Cap}_{q}\left(\cup_{j} E_{j}\right) \leq 2 \sum_{j} \operatorname{Cap}_{q}\left(E_{j}\right)$;
(3) $\operatorname{Cap}_{q}(X)=1$ and $\operatorname{Cap}_{q}(E) \leq 1$ for any $E \subset X$;
(4) if $\left(K_{j}\right)$ is a decreasing sequence of compact sets, $\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Cap}_{q}\left(K_{j}\right)=\operatorname{Cap}_{q}\left(\cap_{n} K_{j}\right)$;
(5) if $\left(E_{j}\right)$ is an increasing sequence of Borel sets, $\operatorname{Cap}_{q}\left(\cup_{j} E_{j}\right)=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Cap}_{q}\left(E_{j}\right)$, that is, $\operatorname{Cap}_{q}$ is a Choquet capacity.
Proof. We note that, due to Example 2.11, in $W_{q}^{*}$, we have

$$
\|\min (\varphi, \psi)\|_{*, q}^{2} \leq 8\left(\|\varphi\|_{*, q}^{2}+\|\psi\|_{*, q}^{2}\right)
$$

Moreover, $\left\|\mathbf{1}_{X}\right\|_{*, q}=1$. We can now follow the proofs of [Vig07, Proposition 27 and Theorem 30] to prove this proposition.

We now show that $\mathrm{Cap}_{q}$ also characterizes pluripolar sets.
Theorem 2.17. There exists a constant $B>0$ such that for all Borel subset $E$ of $X$, we have

$$
B^{-1} \operatorname{Cap}_{\omega}(E) \leq \operatorname{Cap}_{q}(E) \leq B\left(\operatorname{Cap}_{\omega}(E)\right)^{\frac{1}{k \beta^{2}-1}}
$$

In particular, $\operatorname{Cap}_{q}(E)=0$ if and only if $E$ is pluripolar.
Recall that the capacity $\mathrm{Cap}_{\omega}$ was defined by Kołodziej in [Koł03]. It is related to the well-known Bedford-Taylor capacity ([BT82]), and is defined by

$$
\operatorname{Cap}_{\omega}(E)=\sup \left\{\int_{E}\left(\omega+d d^{c} u\right)^{k}: u \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega),-1 \leq u \leq 0\right\}
$$

where $E$ is a Borel subset of $X$. We refer the reader to [GZ05] for more information on this capacity for local and global settings.

We also need the following notion of capacity introduced by Dinh-Sibony in [DS06b]. It is related to the capacities of Alexander in [Ale81] and of Siciak in [Sic62], see also [HL06] and [GZ05]. For a Borel subset $E$ of $X$, we consider the function

$$
V_{E}(x)=\sup \{u(x): u \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega) \text { and } u \leq 0 \text { on } E\}
$$

Then $V_{E}$ is a non-negative $\omega$-psh function. Define

$$
\mathcal{J}(E)=\exp \left(-\sup _{X} V_{E}(x)\right)
$$

Recall from [GZ05, Proposition 6.1] the following relation between $\mathrm{Cap}_{\omega}$ and $\mathcal{J}$.
Lemma 2.18. There is a constant $A>0$ such that for all compact subsets $K$ of $X$, we have

$$
\exp \left(-\frac{A}{\operatorname{Cap}_{\omega}(K)}\right) \leq \mathcal{J}(K) \leq e \cdot \exp \left(-\frac{1}{\operatorname{Cap}_{\omega}(K)^{1 / k}}\right)
$$

Now we can prove Theorem 2.17.
Proof of Theorem 2.17. Due to Example 2.10, if $\varphi$ is a qpsh function such that $\varphi<-1$, then the function $\psi=-\log (-\varphi)$ belongs to $W_{q}^{*}$ for all $q$, and $\psi$ has the same poles set as $\varphi$. We can now follow the proofs of [Vig07, Proposition 28] to see the first inequality.

We now consider the second inequality. We closely follow the proof of [DKN22, Proposition 5.1]. We only need to show this inequality for compact regular sets $K \subset X$ such that $1 \leq M<\infty$ where $M:=\sup _{X} V_{K}(x)$.

Define $f_{K}(x)=\left(V_{K}(x)-M\right) / M$. Then $f_{K}$ is equal -1 on $K$ with $-1 \leq f_{K} \leq 0$ and $f_{K}$ is qpsh with $d d^{c} f_{K}+M^{-1} \omega \geq 0$. Since $f_{K}$ is a bounded qpsh function, it follows from Example 2.10 that $f_{K} \in W_{q}^{*}$ for all $q$.

We now compute $\left\|f_{K}\right\|_{*, q}$. Direct calculation gives us

$$
\begin{gathered}
d f_{K} \wedge d^{c} f_{K}=-f_{K} d d^{c} f_{K}+\frac{1}{2} d d^{c}\left(f_{K}^{2}\right) \leq \frac{\omega}{M}+\frac{1}{2} d d^{c}\left(f_{K}^{2}\right) \\
d\left(f_{K}^{2} / 2\right) \wedge d^{c}\left(f_{K}^{2} / 2\right)=\left(f_{K}^{2}\right) d f_{K} \wedge d^{c} f_{K} \leq d f_{K} \wedge d^{c} f_{K} \leq \frac{\omega}{M}+\frac{1}{2} d d^{c}\left(f_{K}^{2}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence, we can choose $\left(\left(M^{-1}, f_{K}^{2} / 2\right), \ldots,\left(M^{-1}, f_{K}^{2} / 2\right)\right)$ as a defining sequence for $f_{K}$. Moreover, since $\max _{X} f_{K}=0$, we have

$$
\left\|f_{K}\right\|_{L^{1}}=\int_{X}-f_{K} \omega^{n} \leq \frac{A}{M}
$$

for some constant $A$ depending only on $(X, \omega)$ because the set of $\omega$-psh function $u$ such that $\max _{X} u=0$ is a compact subset in $L^{1}(X)$. Thus, we get

$$
\left\|f_{K}\right\|_{*, q} \leq\left\|f_{K}\right\|_{L^{1}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q} \frac{1}{M^{2^{j}}} \leq \frac{A}{M}+\sum_{j=1}^{q} \frac{1}{M^{1 / 2^{j}}} \leq \frac{B^{\prime}}{M^{1 / 2^{q}}}
$$

for some constant $B^{\prime}>0$ since $M \geq 1$.
So, by Lemma 2.18,

$$
\operatorname{Cap}_{q}(U) \leq\left\|f_{K}\right\|_{*, q}^{2} \leq \frac{B^{\prime 2}}{M^{1 / 2^{q-1}}} \leq B\left(\operatorname{Cap}_{\omega}(U)\right)^{\frac{1}{k 2^{q-1}}}
$$

The proof is complete.
Remark 2.19. Theorem 2.17 directly shows that the capacities $\mathrm{Cap}_{q}$ with $p \geq 1$, are equivalent capacities. Observe that the sequence $\left(\mathrm{Cap}_{q}\right)_{q \geq 1}$ is increasing and always bounded above by 1 . Given a Borel set $E$, it is an interesting question to study the behavior of $\mathrm{Cap}_{q}(E)$ as $q$ goes to infinity and their relationship with the Hausdorff measures.

Remark 2.20. As in [Vig07, Remark 33], one can define $\mathrm{Cap}_{q}$ in the local case by the same method. It is also a Choquet capacity and characterizes pluripolar sets.

# 3. MOSER-Trudinger INEQUALITIES 

In this section, we will follow the strategy in [VV23, Section 2] to construct psh bound for functions in $W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$ and prove Theorems 1.2. The key point is that the additional information in the defining sequence will lead to stronger estimates which help us to improve the exponent in the Moser-Trudinger inequalities.

3.1. Set up. As pointed out in Example 2.13, $W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$ is a BMO space for every $q$. Therefore, by [JN61], for compact subset $K$ of $\mathbb{B}$, there are constants $c$ and $A$ such that $\int_{K} e^{c|\varphi|} \omega^{k} \leq A$ for all $\varphi$ in $W_{q}^{*}(X)$ with $\|\varphi\|_{*, q} \leq 1$ (this can also be seen as a consequence of [DMV23, Theorem 1.1]). We will use the following consequence of this fact.
Lemma 3.1. Let $K$ be a compact subset of $\mathbb{B}$ and $m \in \mathbb{N}$. Then there exists a constant $c_{1}>0$ such that, for every $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$ with $\|\varphi\|_{*, q} \leq 1$,

$$
\int_{K}|\varphi|^{m} \omega^{k} \leq c_{1}, \text { where } \omega=d d^{c}|z|^{2}
$$

Let $\varphi$ be a positive function in $W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$ with $\|\varphi\|_{*, q} \leq 1$ and $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ be a defining sequence for $\varphi$ such that

$$
\|\varphi\|_{*, q}=\|\varphi\|_{L^{2}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}
$$

Remark 3.2. Recall that if $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ is a defining sequence for $\varphi$, then $\left(\varphi_{1, \varepsilon}, \ldots, \varphi_{q, \varepsilon}\right)$ is a defining sequence for $\varphi_{\varepsilon}$ where $\varphi_{\varepsilon}$ is the standard regularization of $\varphi$ and $\varphi_{j, \varepsilon}$ is the standard regularization of $\varphi_{j}$ for $j=1, \ldots, q$ (see Theorem 2.14).

We now provide some constructions similar to [VV23]. The different point is that we use data of the last term $\varphi_{q}$ in the defining sequence. Suppose that $\varphi_{q} \leq 0$. For $n>0$, we define $\phi_{n}=\max \left(\varphi_{q},-n\right), h_{n}=1+\phi_{n} / n, T_{n}=d d^{c}\left(h_{n}^{2} / 2\right)$. Then $h_{n} \in \operatorname{PSH}(\mathbb{B}), 0 \leq h_{n} \leq 1$, and $h_{n}=0$ on $\left\{\varphi_{q} \leq-n\right\}$. Moreover, $T_{n}$ is a positive closed $(1,1)$-current that vanishes on the open set $\left\{\varphi_{q}<-n\right\}$.

We have the following lemma similar to [VV23, Lemma 2.2].
Lemma 3.3. Assume that $\varphi_{q-1}$ and $\varphi_{q}$ are smooth. Then the following inequalities holds:
(1) $d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \leq T_{n}$ and $h_{n} d d^{c} h_{n} \leq T_{n}$,
(2) $d \varphi_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{q-1} \leq d d^{c} \phi_{n}$ on $\left\{h_{n}>0\right\}$,
(3) $d \varphi_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{q-1} \wedge T_{n} \leq d d^{c} \phi_{n+1} \wedge T_{n}$,
(4) $h_{n} d \varphi_{q-1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{q-1} \leq n h_{n} d d^{c} h_{n} \leq n T_{n}$.

Similarly to [VV23], for every $m \in \mathbb{N}, K \Subset \mathbb{B}$, we define the following quantities:

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{m, p, K} & =\sup _{v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}} \int_{K} h_{n}^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d d^{c} v_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p} \text { for } 0 \leq p \leq k \\
J_{m, p, K} & =\sup _{v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}} \int_{K} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} d d^{c} v_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1} \text { for } \leq p \leq k-1
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, the supremum taken over all psh functions $v_{j}$ on $\mathbb{B}$ with $0 \leq v_{j} \leq 1$. These quantities can be seen as a higher analogue of the (same notation) quantities in [VV23]. As noted after Theorem 1.2, we use the canonical representative of $\varphi$ here, and thus all the integrals make sense. Note that all definitions depend on $n$. However, we omit the index $n$ as the estimates in the next section do not depend on $n$.
3.2. Estimates. We now prove some estimates for these quantities. As noted in the beginning of this section, the additional data in the defining sequence helps us to prove stronger estimates.

Let $K$ be a compact subset of $\mathbb{B}$. By standard regularization we can assume that $\varphi, \varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}$ are smooth functions in an open neighborhood of $K$. Let $\chi$ be a smooth

cut-off function such that $\chi \equiv 1$ on an open neighborhood of $K$, and $\chi$ is compactly supported on $B$. In what follows, we use $\lesssim$ or $\gtrsim$ to denote $\leq$ or $\geq$, respectively, modulo a multiplicative constant independent of $n$ and $\varphi$ provided $\|\varphi\|_{\kappa, q} \leq 1$.

We first obtain the following lemma, which generalizes [VV23, Lemma 2.3].
Lemma 3.4. There is a constant $c=c_{m, K}$ independent of $\varphi$ and $n$ such that

$$
J_{m, 0, K} \leq c n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}} \text { for every } n
$$

Proof. It is sufficient to prove that

$$
J_{m}=\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}
$$

It follows from the definition of $T_{n}$ and Stokes' formula that

$$
\begin{aligned}
J_{m} & =\frac{1}{2} \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d d^{c} h_{n}^{2} \wedge \omega^{k-1} \\
& =-\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} h_{n}^{2} \wedge \omega^{k-1}-m \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} h_{n}^{2} \wedge \omega^{k-1} \\
& =-2\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} h_{n} d \chi \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}+m \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} h_{n} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ be respectively the first and second integrals inside the brackets. It follows from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, Corollary 3.1 and Lemma 3.3 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{1}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right) \\
& \lesssim\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)} \varphi^{2 m} \wedge \omega^{k}\right) \\
& \lesssim J_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{2}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right) \\
& \leq J_{m} B_{1, m-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
B_{j, m}=\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1} \text { for } j=1, \ldots, q
$$

This implies $J_{m} \lesssim \sqrt{J_{m}}+\sqrt{J_{m}} \sqrt{B_{1, m-1}}$, and hence

$$
J_{m} \lesssim B_{1, m-1}
$$

To estimate $B_{1, m-1}$, we first observe that, by Stokes' formula, for $j=1, \ldots, q-1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
B_{j, m} & =-2\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right. \\
& \left.+m \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}+\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $C_{j, 1}, C_{j, 2}$, and $C_{j, 3}$ be the first, second, and third integrals inside the brackets respectively. It follows from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality that

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{j, 1}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right) \\
& \lesssim\left(\int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)} \varphi^{2 m} \omega^{k}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right) \\
C_{j, 2}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
C_{j, 3}^{2} \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)
$$

It thus follows from the definition of the defining sequence, Corollary 3.1, Lemma 3.3, and inequality (3.1) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C_{j, 1}^{2} \lesssim \begin{cases}B_{j+1, m} & \text { if } j<q-1 \\
n B_{1, m-1} & \text { if } j=q-1\end{cases} \quad C_{j, 2}^{2} \lesssim \begin{cases}B_{1, m-1} B_{j+1, m} & \text { if } j<q-1 \\
n B_{1, m-1}^{2} & \text { if } j=q-1\end{cases} \\
& C_{j, 3}^{2} \lesssim \begin{cases}B_{1, m-1} B_{j+1, m} & \text { if } j<q-1 \\
n B_{1, m-1}^{2} & \text { if } j=q-1\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that we use (3.1) and the fact that $0 \leq h_{n} \leq 1$ when $j=q-1$.
Then we have

$$
B_{j, m}^{2} \lesssim \begin{cases}B_{j+1, m}+B_{1, m-1} B_{j+1, m} & \text { if } j<q-1 \\ n B_{1, m-1}^{2} & \text { if } j=q-1\end{cases}
$$

which implies

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
B_{j, m}^{2} \lesssim B_{1, m-1} B_{j+1, m} \text { for } j<q-1 \\
B_{q-1, m} \lesssim \sqrt{n} B_{1, m-1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

and hence,

$$
B_{1, m}^{2^{q-2}} \lesssim B_{q-1, m} B_{1, m-1}^{2^{q-2}-1} \lesssim \sqrt{n} B_{1, m-1}^{2^{q-2}}
$$

It thus follows that

$$
B_{1, m} \lesssim n^{\frac{1}{2^{q-1}}} B_{1, m-1}
$$

and hence

$$
B_{1, m} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}
$$

Now, combining inequalities (3.1) and (3.2) gives us

$$
J_{m} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}
$$

as desired.
The following lemma generalizes [VV23, Lemma 2.4].
Lemma 3.5. There is a constant $c=c_{m, K}$ independent of $\varphi$ and $n$ such that

$$
J_{m, p, K} \leq c n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}} \text { for every } n
$$

Proof. We prove the lemma by induction in $p$. If $p=0$, the desired assertion is Lemma 3.4. Assume now that it is true for all $p^{\prime}$ with $p^{\prime} \leq p-1$. It is sufficient to prove that

$$
J_{m, p}=\sup _{v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}} \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} d d^{c} v_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{k-1}}}
$$

where the supremum taken over all psh functions $v_{j}$ on $\mathbb{B}$ with $0 \leq v_{j} \leq 1$.
We prove this inequality by induction on $m$ ( $p$ now fixed). When $m=0$, it is obvious. Assume that it is true for all $m^{\prime}$ with $m^{\prime} \leq m-1$. Let $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$ be psh functions in $\mathbb{B}$ that take values in $[0,1]$. We set $R=d d^{c} v_{2} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge T_{n} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1}$. It follows from Stokes' formula that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} d d^{c} v_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1} \\
& \quad=-2\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R+m \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $D_{1}$ and $D_{2}$ be the first and second integrals inside the brackets respectively. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, the induction hypothesis on $p$, the induction hypothesis on $m$, and Lemma 3.3, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{1}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \varphi^{2 m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge R\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d v_{1} \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R\right) \\
& \lesssim\left(\int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)} \varphi^{2 m} R \wedge \omega\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d d^{c}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right) \wedge R\right) \\
& \lesssim J_{m, p-1, \operatorname{supp}(\chi)} J_{m, p} \\
& \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{k-1}}} J_{m, p}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{2}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge R\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d v_{1} \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R\right) \\
& \lesssim\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge R\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d d^{c}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right) \wedge R\right) \\
& \lesssim E_{1, m-1} J_{m, p}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
E_{j, m}=\sup _{v_{2}, \ldots, v_{p}} \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R \text { for } j=1, \ldots, q
$$

Note that since $\chi$ depends on $K$, the estimate here only depends on $K$.
Then by taking the supremum over all such $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$, we observe that

$$
J_{m, p} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{k-1}}}+E_{1, m-1}
$$

To estimate $E_{1, m-1}$, we consider $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$ as above. It follows from Stokes' formula that, for $j=1, \ldots, q-1$,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R=-2\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R+m \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right)
$$

Let $F_{j, 1}$ and $F_{j, 2}$ be the first and second integrals inside the brackets respectively. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, the induction hypothesis on $p$, and the induction hypothesis

on $m$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{j, 1}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \varphi^{2 m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge R\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right) \\
& \lesssim J_{m, p-1, \operatorname{supp}(\chi)}\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right) \\
& \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{j, 2}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge R\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge R\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right) \\
& \leq E_{1, m-1}\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the supremum over all such $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$, using Lemma 3.3 and inequality (3.3), we have

$$
E_{j, m}^{2} \lesssim \begin{cases}E_{j+1, m}\left(E_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\right) & \text { if } j<q-1 \\ n\left(n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\left(n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}+E_{1, m-1}\right)+E_{1, m-1}\left(n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}+E_{1, m-1}\right)\right) & \text { if } j=q-1\end{cases}
$$

It thus follows that

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
E_{j, m}^{2} \lesssim E_{j+1, m}\left(E_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\right) \text { if } j<q-1 \\
E_{q-1, m} \lesssim \sqrt{n}\left(E_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Then we have

$$
E_{1, m}^{2^{q-2}} \leq E_{q-1, m}\left(E_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\right)^{2^{q-2}-1} \lesssim \sqrt{n}\left(E_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\right)^{2^{q-2}}
$$

and hence,

$$
E_{1, m} \lesssim n^{\frac{1}{2^{2-1}}}\left(E_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}\right)
$$

Therefore, we obtain

$$
E_{1, m} \lesssim n^{\frac{m+1}{2^{2-1}}}
$$

Combining inequalities (3.3) and (3.4) gives us

$$
J_{m, p} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}
$$

as desired.
Finally, we estimate $I_{m, p, K}$, these estimates generalize [VV23, Lemma 2.5].
Lemma 3.6. There is a constant $c=c(m, K)$ independent of $\varphi$ and $n$ such that

$$
I_{m, p, K} \leq c n^{\frac{m}{2^{2-1}}}
$$

for every $n$.

Proof. We argue similarly as in the proof of Lemma 3.5, by induction on $p$. If $p=0$, the desired assertion follows from Corollary 3.1. We assume now that it is true for every $p^{\prime}$ with $p^{\prime} \leq p-1$. To prove the desired assertion, it suffices to prove that

$$
I_{m, p}=\sup _{v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}} \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} v_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}
$$

where the supremum taken over all psh functions $v_{j}$ on $\mathbb{B}$ with $0 \leq v_{j} \leq 1$.
We prove this inequality by induction on $m$ ( $p$ now fixed). When $m=0$, it is obvious. Assume that it is true for all $m^{\prime}$ with $m^{\prime} \leq m-1$. Let $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$ be psh functions take value in $[0,1]$. We set $R^{\prime}=d d^{c} v_{2} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} v_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p}$. It follows from Stokes' formula that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime} & =-2\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \chi \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}+m \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $G_{1}, G_{2}$, and $G_{3}$ be the first, second, and third integrals inside the brackets respectively. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, the induction hypothesis on $p$, the induction hypothesis on $m$, and Lemma 3.5, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{1}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} h_{n}^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} h_{n}^{2} \varphi^{2 m} \chi^{2} d v_{1} \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \lesssim I_{m, p-1, \operatorname{supp}(\chi)}\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} h_{n}^{2} \varphi^{2 m} \chi^{2} d d^{c}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right) \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}} I_{m, p} \\
G_{2}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d v_{1} \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right) \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq J_{m, p-1, \operatorname{supp}(\chi)} I_{m, p} \\
& \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}} I_{m, p}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{3}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d v_{1} \wedge d^{c} v_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right) \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq H_{1, m-1} I_{m, p}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
H_{j, m}=\sup _{v_{2}, \ldots, v_{p}} \int_{\mathbb{B}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime} \text { for } j=1, \ldots, q
$$

Then, by taking the supremum over all sucht $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$, we have

$$
I_{m, p} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}+H_{1, m-1}
$$

To estimate $H_{1, m-1}$, we consider $v_{2}, \ldots, v_{p}$ as above. It follows from Stokes' formula that, for $j=1, \ldots, q-1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime} & =-2\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}+\right. \\
& \left.m \int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-1} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}+\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $L_{j, 1}, L_{j, 2}$, and $L_{j, 3}$ be the first, second, and third integrals inside the brackets respectively. It follows from Lemma 3.3, Lemma 3.5, Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the induction hypothesis on $p$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{j, 1}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} \wedge R^{\prime} \wedge \omega\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq I_{m, p-1, \operatorname{supp}(\chi)}\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{\delta-1}}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
L_{j, 2}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m-2} h_{n}^{2} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \lesssim H_{1, m-1}\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{j, 3}^{2} & \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} d h_{n} \wedge d^{c} h_{n} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} T_{n} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq J_{m, p-1, \operatorname{supp}(\chi)}\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right) \\
& \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{\delta-1}}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}} \chi^{2} \varphi^{2 m} h_{n}^{2} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge R^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the supremum over all such $v_{2}, \ldots, v_{p}$, using Lemma 3.3, Lemma 3.5, and inequality (3.5), we have

$$
H_{j, m}^{2} \lesssim\left\{\begin{array}{l}
H_{j+1, m}\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{\delta-1}}}\right) \text { if } j<q-1 \\
n\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{\delta-1}}}\right)^{2} \text { if } j=q-1
\end{array}\right.
$$

It thus follows that

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
H_{k, m}^{2} \lesssim H_{k+1, m}\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{\delta-1}}}\right) \text { if } k<q-1 \\
H_{q-1, m} \lesssim \sqrt{n}\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{\delta-1}}}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

and hence

$$
H_{1, m-1}^{2^{q-2}} \lesssim H_{q-1, m}\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}\right)^{2^{q-2}-1} \lesssim \sqrt{n}\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}\right)^{2^{q-2}}
$$

Then we have

$$
H_{1, m} \lesssim n^{\frac{1}{2^{q-1}}}\left(H_{1, m-1}+n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}\right)
$$

which implies

$$
H_{1, m} \lesssim n^{\frac{m+1}{2^{q-1}}}
$$

Combining inequalities (3.5) and (3.6) gives

$$
I_{m, p} \lesssim n^{\frac{m}{2^{q-1}}}
$$

as desired.
3.3. Bounding by plurisubharmonic functions. With all these estimates in hand, we can now construct a psh bound for functions in $W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$.
Theorem 3.7. Let $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(\mathbb{B})$ with $\|\varphi\|_{*, q} \leq 1$ and $\alpha \in\left[1,2^{q}\right)$. Then for every compact subset $K$ of $\mathbb{B}$, there exist a constant $C>0$ and a psh function $u$ on $\mathbb{B}$ such that

$$
|\varphi|^{\alpha} \leq-u \text { on } K \text { and }\|u\|_{L^{1}(K)} \leq C
$$

Proof. The proof of this theorem is almost line by line with the proof of [VV23, Theorem 1.3] (just change the coefficient form 1 to $q$ ). We only present the construction and refer the reader to the cited paper for details of the proof.

Write $\varphi=\max (\varphi, 0)+\min (\varphi, 0)$, we can assume that $\varphi \geq 0$. Fix $\alpha \in\left[1,2^{q}\right)$ and choose a constant $\lambda \in\left(\max \left(2^{\alpha}, 2^{2^{q-1}}\right), 2^{2^{q}}\right)$. For $n \in \mathbb{N}$, we set

$$
K_{n}=\left\{z \in K: \varphi(z) \geq 2^{n}, \varphi_{q} \geq-\lambda^{n}\right\}
$$

Define the extremal functions

$$
u_{n}=u_{K_{n}}:=\sup \left\{u \in \operatorname{PSH}(\mathbb{B}): u \leq 0 \text { on } \mathbb{B}, u \leq-1 \text { on } K_{n}\right\}
$$

Let $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{q}\right)$ be a defining sequence for $\varphi$ such that

$$
\|\varphi\|_{*, q}=\|\varphi\|_{L^{2}}+\sum_{j=1}^{q}\left\|d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right\|^{1 / 2^{j}}
$$

Assume that $\varphi_{q} \leq 0$. Define

$$
u=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} 2^{n \alpha}\left(u_{n}^{*}+\frac{\max \left(\varphi_{q},-\lambda^{n}\right)}{\lambda^{n}}\right)
$$

where $u_{n}^{*}$ is the usc regularization of $u_{n}$. This is our desired function.
Example 3.8. (Sharpness of the exponential $\alpha$ ) As in [VV23, page 13], we consider the case where $\alpha>2^{q}$ and $k=1$. We choose the function $\varphi$ to be $\left(-\log |z|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2^{q}-\delta}$ where $\delta \in\left(0,1 / 2^{q}\right)$. Then by Example 2.12, $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}$. Since $\alpha>2^{q}$, we can choose $\delta$ small enough such that $\beta=\alpha\left(1 / 2^{q}-\delta\right)>1$. Thus, $\varphi^{\alpha}=\left(-\log |z|^{2}\right)^{\beta}$ and then $e^{c \varphi^{\alpha}} \geq c /|z|^{2}$ which is not locally integrable at 0 in $\mathbb{C}$. Also, note that by arguments in [VV23], this function is not bounded from above by minus of a subharmonic function. So, the exponential coefficient here as well as the one in Theorem 1.2 cannot be greater than $2^{q}$. It is natural to predict

that the result still holds for $\alpha=2^{q}$ (like in the case $q=1$ ), but currently, we do not know how to prove that.

One can argue similarly to the proof of Theorem 3.7 to obtain the following global version of psh bound. We refer the reader to [VV23, Theorem 2.7] for more details.

Theorem 3.9. Let $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$ with $\|\varphi\|_{s, q} \leq 1$ and $\alpha \in\left[1,2^{q}\right)$. Then there exist a strictly positive constant $C$ not depending on $\varphi$ and a negative $C \omega$-psh $u$ on $X$ such that

$$
|\varphi|^{\alpha} \leq-u \quad \text { and } \quad\|u\|_{L^{1}(X)} \leq C
$$

This theorem implies the following global Moser-Trudinger inequality.
Theorem 3.10. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of dimension $k$. Let $q \geq 1$ and $\alpha \in\left[1,2^{q}\right)$. Let $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{k}$ be $\omega$-psh functions which are Hölder continuous of Hölder exponent $\beta$ with $\left\|v_{j}\right\|_{\mathscr{C} \beta} \leq 1$ for $1 \leq j \leq k$. Let $\varphi \in W_{q}^{*}(X)$ such that $\|\varphi\|_{s, q} \leq 1$. Then there exist strictly positive constants $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ depending on $X, \omega, \alpha$ and $\beta$ but independent of $\varphi, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{k}$ such that

$$
\int_{X} e^{c_{1}|\varphi|^{\alpha}}\left(\omega+d d^{c} v_{1}\right) \wedge \cdots \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} v_{k}\right) \leq c_{2}
$$

# 4. COMPLEX MONGE-AMPÈRE EQUATION 

In this section, we study the relationship between $W_{q}^{*}$ and the complex Monge-Ampère operator.
4.1. Global setting. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of dimension $k$. We recall some definitions from [GZ07]. Let $\varphi$ be some unbounded $\omega$-psh function on $X$ and consider $\varphi_{j}=\max (\varphi,-j)$ be the canonical approximation of $\varphi$ by bounded $\omega$-psh functions. By [BT87], we can define the Monge-Ampère measure $\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k}$. The sequence of measures

$$
\mathbf{1}_{\{\varphi>-j\}}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k}
$$

is an increasing sequence and converges to the non-pluripolar Monge-Ampère measure $\mu_{\varphi}$ of $\varphi$. Its total mass $\mu_{\varphi}(X)$ can take any value in $\left[0, \int_{X} \omega^{k}\right]$. Define

$$
\mathcal{E}(X, \omega)=\left\{\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega): \mu_{\varphi}(X)=\int_{X} \omega^{k}\right\}
$$

Recall the following criterion for functions in $\mathcal{E}(X, \omega)$.
Lemma 4.1. [GZ07, Lemma 1.2] Let $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ and define $\varphi_{j}=\max (\varphi,-j)$ for $j \in \mathbb{N}$. Let $\left(s_{j}\right)$ be any sequence of real numbers converging to $\infty$, such that $s_{j} \leq j$ for all $j \in \mathbb{N}$. Then the following conditions are equivalent:
(1) $\varphi \in \mathcal{E}(X, \omega)$;
(2) $\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k}(\varphi \leq-j) \rightarrow 0$;
(3) $\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k}\left(\varphi \leq-s_{j}\right) \rightarrow 0$.

Now, we prove that any $\omega$-psh complex Sobolev function belongs to $\mathcal{E}(X, \omega)$.

Proof of Theorem 1.3(1). Assume that $\varphi$ is a negative $\omega$-psh function in $W_{1}^{*}(X)$ and $\varphi_{j}=$ $\max (\varphi,-j)$. We note that $\varphi_{j} / j$ equals to -1 when $\varphi \leq-j$ and equals to $\varphi / j<0$ when $\varphi>-j$. Let $T_{\varphi}$ be a positive closed current on $X$ such that $d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq T_{\varphi}$. By Example 2.11, we have $d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \leq T_{\varphi}$. By Stokes' formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\{\varphi \leq-j\}}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k} & \leq-\int_{X} \frac{\varphi_{j}}{j}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k} \\
& =\frac{1}{j}\left(\int_{X} d \varphi_{j} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{j} \wedge \sum_{m=0}^{k-1}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k-1-m} \wedge \omega^{m}-\int_{X} \varphi_{j} \omega^{k}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{j}\left(\int_{X} T_{\varphi} \wedge \sum_{m=0}^{k-1}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k-1-m} \wedge \omega^{m}-\int_{X} \varphi \omega^{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $T_{\varphi}$ is closed, the first integral doesn't change if we replace the closed current $\sum_{m=0}^{k-1}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k-1-m} \wedge \omega^{m}$ by a closed form in its de Rham cohomology class. We can replace it by $k \omega^{k-1}$ and obtain

$$
\int_{\{\varphi \leq-j\}}\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{k} \leq \frac{k \cdot\left\|T_{\varphi}\right\|_{X}}{j}-\frac{1}{j}\left(\int_{X} \varphi \omega^{k}\right) \rightarrow 0 \text { as } j \rightarrow \infty
$$

This, combined with Lemma 4.1, finishes our proof.
Next, we recall the definition of finite energy classes in [GZ07]. For simplicity, assume that $\int_{X} \omega^{k}=1$ and denote $\omega_{\varphi}:=\omega+d d^{c} \varphi$. Let $p>0$ and $\varphi$ be a bounded $\omega$-psh functions, one can define the energy functional

$$
E_{p}(\varphi)=-\frac{1}{k+1} \sum_{m=0}^{k} \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{p}\left(\omega_{\varphi}\right)^{m} \wedge \omega^{k-m}
$$

We can extend this functional for arbitrary $\omega$-psh functions by canonical approximation

$$
E_{p}(\varphi)=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} E_{p}\left(\varphi_{j}\right)
$$

The finite energy class is defined as follows

$$
\mathcal{E}^{p}(X, \omega)=\left\{\varphi \in \mathcal{E}(X, \omega): E_{p}(\varphi)>-\infty\right\}
$$

To prove Theorem 1.3(2), we first recall some facts about finite energy classes. We only use the results for the class $\mathcal{E}^{p}(X, \omega)$ with $p \geq 1$. For more general classes and the proof of these propositions, we refer the readers to [GZ07] and [DV22].
Proposition 4.2. Let $p \geq 1$ and $\varphi, \psi$ be bounded non-positive $\omega$-psh functions. Then for every positive closed current $T$ of bi-dimension $(1,1)$, we have

$$
0 \leq \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{p} \omega_{\psi} \wedge T \leq 2 p \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{p} \omega_{\varphi} \wedge T+2 p \int_{X}(-\psi)^{p} \omega_{\psi} \wedge T
$$

Proposition 4.3. Let $p \geq 1$ and $\varphi_{0}, \ldots, \varphi_{k}$ be bounded non-positive $\omega$-psh functions. Then there exists a strictly positive constant $C_{p}$ depending only on $p$ such that

$$
\int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{0}\right)^{p} \omega_{\varphi_{1}} \wedge \cdots \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{k}} \leq C_{p} \max _{0 \leq m \leq k}\left(\int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{m}\right)^{p} \omega_{\varphi_{m}}^{k}\right)
$$

We will use the following direct corollary.

Corollary 4.4. Let $\varphi$ and $\psi$ be non-positive functions in $\mathcal{E}^{p}(X, \omega)$ with $p \geq 1$. Then for $0 \leq m \leq k-1$, there exists a strictly positive constant $C_{p}$ depending only on $p$ such that

$$
\int_{X}(-\varphi)^{p} \omega_{\psi} \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{k-m-1} \wedge \omega^{m} \leq C_{p}\left(\int_{X}(-\varphi)^{p} \omega_{\varphi}^{k}+\int_{X}(-\psi)^{p} \omega_{\psi}^{k}\right)
$$

Here the measure $\omega_{\psi} \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{k-m-1} \wedge \omega^{m}$ is defined in the non-pluripolar sense (see [GZ17, Chapter 10.2.3].

Proof. Let $\varphi_{j}=\max (\varphi,-j)$ and $\psi_{j}=\max (\psi,-j)$. By [GZ17, Theorem 10.18],

$$
\int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{j}\right)^{p} \omega_{\psi} \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{k-m-1} \wedge \omega^{m}=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{j}\right)^{p} \omega_{\psi_{j^{\prime}}} \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{j^{\prime}}}^{k-m-1} \wedge \omega^{m}
$$

By Proposition 4.3, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{j}\right)^{p} \omega_{\psi_{j^{\prime}}} \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{j^{\prime}}}^{k-m-1} \wedge \omega^{m} & \leq C_{p}\left(\int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{j}\right)^{p} \omega_{\varphi_{j}}^{k}+\int_{X}\left(-\varphi_{j^{\prime}}\right)^{p} \omega_{\varphi_{j^{\prime}}}^{k}+\int_{X}\left(-\psi_{j^{\prime}}\right)^{p} \omega_{\psi_{j^{\prime}}}^{k}\right) \\
& \leq C_{p}\left(\int_{X}(-\varphi)^{p} \omega_{\varphi}^{k}+\int_{X}(-\psi)^{p} \omega_{\psi}^{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting $j^{\prime} \rightarrow \infty$ and then let $j \rightarrow \infty$ give us the result.
Proof of Theorem 1.3(2). We prove this by induction. First, consider the case where $q=$ 2. Let $\psi$ be the function in $W_{i}^{*}(X)$ such that $d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq C\left(\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right)$. By Theorem 1.3(1), we have $\varphi, \psi \in \mathcal{E}(X, \omega)$. By Stokes' formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{X} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{l} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1} & =\int_{X} \varphi d d^{c} \varphi \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{l} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1} \\
& =\int_{X} \varphi \omega_{\varphi}^{l+1} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1}-\int_{X} \varphi \omega_{\varphi}^{l} \wedge \varphi^{k-l}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we can control the energy of $\varphi$ through $\psi$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
-E_{1}(\varphi) & =\frac{1}{k+1} \sum_{m=0}^{k} \int_{X}(-\varphi) \omega_{\varphi}^{m} \wedge \omega^{k-m} \\
& =\int_{X}(-\varphi) \omega^{k}+\frac{1}{k+1} \sum_{m=1}^{k} \sum_{l=0}^{m-1} \int_{X} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{l} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1} \\
& \leq \int_{X}(-\varphi) \omega^{k}+\frac{C}{k+1} \sum_{m=1}^{k} \sum_{l=0}^{m-1} \int_{X} \omega_{\psi} \wedge \omega_{\varphi}^{l} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1} \\
& =\int_{X}(-\varphi) \omega^{k}+\frac{C}{k+1} \sum_{m=1}^{k} \sum_{l=0}^{m-1} 1<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

So, $\varphi \in \mathcal{E}^{1}(X, \omega)$.
Suppose that the theorem is true for $q-1$ with $q>2$. Let $\psi$ be an $\omega$-psh function in $W_{q-1}^{*}(X)$ such that $d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \leq C\left(\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right)$. By the induction hypothesis, we have $\varphi, \psi \in \mathcal{E}^{q-2}(X, \omega)$. We observe that

$$
d d^{c}\left((-\varphi)^{q} / q\right)=(q-1)(-\varphi)^{q-2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi-(-\varphi)^{q-1} d d^{c} \varphi
$$

By using Stokes's formula, we can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-1} d d^{c} \varphi \wedge T & =(q-1) \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge T-\int_{X} d d^{c}\left((-\varphi)^{q} / q\right) \wedge T \\
& =(q-1) \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge T
\end{aligned}
$$

for $T$ is a sufficiently regular positive closed current of bi-dimension $(1,1)$. This implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
-E_{q-1}(\varphi) & =\frac{1}{k+1} \sum_{m=0}^{k} \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-1}\left(\omega_{\varphi}\right)^{m} \wedge \omega^{k-m} \\
& =\int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-1} \omega^{k}+\frac{q-1}{k+1} \sum_{m=1}^{k} \sum_{l=0}^{m-1} \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-2} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi \wedge\left(\omega_{\varphi}\right)^{l} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1} \\
& \leq \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-1} \omega^{k}+\frac{C(q-1)}{k+1} \sum_{m=1}^{k} \sum_{l=0}^{m-1} \int_{X}(-\varphi)^{q-2} \omega_{\varphi} \wedge\left(\omega_{\varphi}\right)^{l} \wedge \omega^{k-l-1} \\
& <\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

by applying Corollary 4.4 for $p=q-2$ and the induction hypothesis. So $\varphi \in \mathcal{E}^{q-1}(X, \omega)$ and we complete our proof.

Remark 4.5. The above theorem provides a lower bound for $p(q)$ by $q-1$. From Example 3.8 and [DGL21, Theorem 2.1], we see that $p(q)$ has an upper bound by $k\left(2^{q}-1\right)$. It is an interesting question to know which is the best option for $p(q)$. One can also ask if the envelope method in [DGL21] can be used to give a new proof for the Moser-Trudinger inequalities. It has been noted in the beginning of Section 3, as a consequence of bounded mean oscillation property, there are constants $c$ and $A$ such that $\int_{X} e^{c\|\varphi\|} \omega^{k} \leq A$ for all $\varphi$ in $W_{q}^{*}(X)$ with $\|\varphi\|_{*, q} \leq 1$. This fact can be used in place of Skoda's integrability theorem in the proof of Theorem 2.1 in [DGL21].
4.2. Local setting. The following result is the key point in our proof of Theorem 1.4.

Proposition 4.6. Let $1 \leq p \leq k-1$ and $0 \leq m \leq k-p$. Let $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{p+1}$ be integers satisfying $q_{1} \leq \cdots \leq q_{p+1}, q_{j} \geq p-1+m$ for $1 \leq j \leq p$, and $q_{p} \leq q_{1}+1$. Let $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{p+1}$ be negative smooth psh functions on $\Omega$ such that, for $j=1, \ldots, p+1,\left\|\varphi_{j}\right\|_{*, q_{j}} \leq 1$. Assume that there exists a defining sequence $\left(\varphi_{j, 1}, \ldots, \varphi_{j, q_{j}}\right)$ of $\varphi_{j}$ such that $\varphi_{j, l}$ is smooth for $l=1, \ldots, q_{j}$, $\left\|\varphi_{j, l}\right\|_{*, q_{j}-l} \leq 1$ for $l=1, \ldots, q_{j}-1$ and $\left\|\varphi_{j, q_{j}}\right\|_{L^{1}} \leq 1$. Then for every compact subset $K$ of $\Omega$, there is a constant $C>0$ depending only on $K, m$ and $p$ such that

$$
\int_{K}\left(-\varphi_{p+1}\right)^{m} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p} \leq C \text { where } \omega=d d^{c}|z|^{2}
$$

Proof. We prove the result by induction on $p$ and $m$. Fix a compact set $K$ and a cut-off function $\chi$ on $\Omega$ such that $0 \leq \chi \leq 1$ and $\chi=1$ on $K$. In our estimates, $\lesssim$ denotes $\leq$ modulo a multiplicative constant depending only on $m$ and $K$.

Consider the case where $p=1$. If $m=0$, then the desired property follows as $\left\|\varphi_{1}\right\|_{*, 1} \leq$ 1. Assume that the desired property is true for $0, \ldots, m-1$ for some $1 \leq m \leq k-p$. We now prove this for $m$. By hypothesis, $q_{2} \geq q_{1} \geq m$. Hence, there exist smooth psh

functions $\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}$ satisfying $\left\|\psi_{1}\right\|_{*, m-1} \leq 1,\left\|\psi_{2}\right\|_{*, m-1} \leq 1$ such that

$$
d \varphi_{1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{1} \leq d d^{c} \psi_{1}, \quad d \varphi_{2} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{2} \leq d d^{c} \psi_{2}
$$

By Stokes' formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{K}\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1} & \lesssim\left|\int_{\Omega} \chi\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m-1} d \varphi_{2} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right| \\
& +\left|\int_{\Omega}\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term, by using Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and inequalities (4.1), we can bound it from above by the square root of

$$
\left(\int_{\Omega} \chi\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m-1} d d^{c} \psi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\Omega} \chi\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m-1} d d^{c} \psi_{2} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)
$$

It follows from the induction hypothesis for $m-1$ that both factors are bounded by a constant depending only on $\operatorname{supp}(\chi)$ (and hence only on $K$ ). Hence, the first term of the RHS of inequality (4.2) is bounded by a constant depending only on $K$. For the second term of the RHS of inequality (4.2), by using Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and inequalities (4.1), we can bound it from above by the square root of

$$
\left(\int_{\Omega}\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m+1} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)\left(\int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)}\left(-\varphi_{2}\right)^{m-1} d d^{c} \psi_{1} \wedge \omega^{k-1}\right)
$$

We use the induction hypothesis for $m-1$ for the second factor. The first factor can be bounded using Corollary 3.1. Hence, the second term of the RHS of inequality (4.2) is bounded by a constant depending only on $K$. The proof for the case $p=1$ is thus complete.

Now, we consider the case where $p>1$. Assume that the desired property is true for $p-1$, where $2 \leq p \leq k-1$. We prove that this is true for $p$. Consider the case where $m=0$. We note that

$$
d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p}=d d^{c}\left(\varphi_{p} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1}\right)
$$

Hence, by Stokes' formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{K} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p} & \leq \int_{\Omega} \chi d d^{c}\left(\varphi_{p} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1}\right) \wedge \omega^{k-p} \\
& =\int_{\Omega}\left(-\varphi_{p}\right) d d^{c} \chi \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p} \\
& \lesssim \int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)}\left(-\varphi_{p}\right) d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

We now only need to check that $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{p}$ satisfy the induction hypothesis for $p-1$ and $m=1$. This is clear because $q_{p-1} \leq q_{p} \leq q_{1}+1$ and $q_{j} \geq p-1=(p-1)-1+1$ for $1 \leq j \leq p-1$. Therefore, we get the statement for $m=0$.

Assume that the statement is true for $0, \ldots, m-1$, where $1 \leq m \leq k-p$. We now prove this for $m$. Since $q_{p+1} \geq q_{p}$, there exist smooth psh functions $\phi_{p}, \phi_{p+1}$ satisfying $\left\|\phi_{p}\right\|_{*, q_{p}-1} \leq 1,\left\|\phi_{p+1}\right\|_{*, q_{p}-1} \leq 1$ such that

$$
d \varphi_{p} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{p} \leq d d^{c} \phi_{p}, \quad d \varphi_{p+1} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{p+1} \leq d d^{c} \phi_{p+1}
$$

We need to bound, for $\varphi=\varphi_{p+1}$,

$$
\int_{\Omega} \chi(-\varphi)^{m} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p}
$$

By Stokes' formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Omega} \chi(-\varphi)^{m} d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p} \\
& \lesssim\left|\int_{\Omega}(-\varphi)^{m} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{p} \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p}\right| \\
& +\left|\int_{\Omega} \chi(-\varphi)^{m-1} d \varphi \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{p} \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

For the second term of the RHS of inequality (4.4), by using Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and inequalities (4.3), we can bound it from above by the square root of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\int_{\Omega} \chi(-\varphi)^{m-1} d d^{c} \phi_{p} \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p}\right) \\
& \times\left(\int_{\Omega} \chi(-\varphi)^{m-1} d d^{c} \phi_{p+1} \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We note that $q_{p}-1, q_{1}, \ldots, q_{p-1}, q_{p+1}$ satisfy induction hypothesis for $p$ and $m-1$. Thus, both factors are bounded by a constant depending only on $\operatorname{supp}(\chi)$ (and hence only on $K)$. Hence, the second term of the RHS of inequality (4.4) is bounded by a constant depending only on $K$. For the first term of the RHS of inequality (4.4), by using CauchySchwarz inequality and inequalities (4.3), we can bound it from above by the square root of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\int_{\Omega}(-\varphi)^{m+1} d \chi \wedge d^{c} \chi \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p}\right) \\
& \times\left(\int_{\operatorname{supp}(\chi)}(-\varphi)^{m-1} d d^{c} \phi_{p} \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d d^{c} \varphi_{p-1} \wedge \omega^{k-p}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is clear that $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{p-1}, q_{p+1}$ satisfy induction hypothesis for $p-1$ and $m+1$ and $q_{p}-1, q_{1}, \ldots, q_{p-1}, q_{p+1}$ satisfy induction hypothesis for $p$ and $m-1$. Thus, we can bound (4.5) by a constant depending only on $K$. Therefore, we can bound the first term of the RHS of inequality (4.4). The proof is complete.

We now prove that psh $q$-complex Sobolev functions belong to $\mathcal{D}(\Omega)$ for $q \geq k-1$.
End of proof of Theorem 1.4. Let $\varphi \in W_{k-1, \text { loc }}^{*}(\Omega) \cap \operatorname{PSH}(\Omega)$. Since the problem is local, we can assume that $\varphi \in W_{k-1}^{*}(\Omega) \cap \operatorname{PSH}(\Omega)$. We will prove that $\varphi$ satisfies the condition (1.1). Let $U$ be an open relatively compact subset of $\Omega$ and $\left(\varphi_{n}\right)$ be the sequence of smooth psh functions constructed in the proof of Theorem 2.14. We note that $\left\|\varphi_{n}\right\|_{W_{k-1}^{*}(U)} \leq$ $2\|\varphi\|_{W_{k-1}^{*}(\Omega)}$ for every $n$. Let $\left(\varphi_{0,1}, \ldots, \varphi_{0, k-1}\right)$ be a smooth defining sequence for $\varphi$. By the proof of Theorem 2.14, we can construct a smooth defining sequence $\left(\varphi_{n, 1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n, k-1}\right)$ for $\varphi_{n}$ such that $\left\|\varphi_{n, l}\right\|_{W_{k-1-l}^{*}(U)} \leq 2\left\|\varphi_{0, l}\right\|_{W_{k-1-l}^{*}(\Omega)}$ for $1 \leq l \leq k-2,\left\|\varphi_{n, k-1}\right\|_{L^{1}(U)} \leq$ $2\left\|\varphi_{0, k-1}\right\|_{L^{1}(\Omega)}$, for every $n$. Rescale $\varphi$ if necessary, we can assume that, for every $n$, $\left\|\varphi_{n}\right\|_{W_{k-1}^{*}(U)} \leq 1,\left\|\varphi_{n, l}\right\|_{W_{k-1-l}^{*}(U)} \leq 1$ for $1 \leq l \leq k-2$ and $\left\|\varphi_{n, k-1}\right\|_{L^{1}(U)} \leq 1$.

Since $d \varphi_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{n} \leq d d^{c} \varphi_{n, 1}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{U}\left|\varphi_{n}\right|^{k-p-2} d \varphi_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{n} \wedge\left(d d^{c} \varphi_{n}\right)^{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1} \\
& \leq \int_{U}\left|\varphi_{n}\right|^{k-p-2} d d^{c} \varphi_{n, 1} \wedge\left(d d^{c} \varphi_{n}\right)^{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from Proposition 4.6 that the right-hand side is uniformly bounded by a constant depending only on $U$. Therefore, $\left|\varphi_{n}\right|^{k-p-2} d \varphi_{n} \wedge d^{c} \varphi_{n} \wedge\left(d d^{c} \varphi_{n}\right)^{p} \wedge \omega^{k-p-1}$ are locally weakly bounded in $U$ for every $p=0, \ldots, k-2$. The proof is complete.

abstract:
We study higher complex Sobolev spaces and their corresponding functional
capacities. In particular, we prove the Moser-Trudinger inequality for these
spaces and discuss some relationships between these spaces and the complex
Monge-Amp\`{e}re equation.
